claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 106:
(1) A subagent represents the principal with respect to acts within the scope of the authority thereof.
(2) A subagent has the same rights and obligations as an agent in relation to the principal and third parties within the scope of that subagent's authority.
(Abuse of Authority to Represent)



        Conclusion:
        A guardian of adult may not appoint its sub-agent unless there is an unavoidable reason to do so..'''
argument: The given argument does not logically entail the conclusion because Article 106 does not specify any restrictions on subagents appointed by guardians of adults, nor does it mention the necessity of an 'unavoidable reason' for appointing a sub-agent. The conclusion introduces a new condition ('unavoidable reason') not supported by the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 353:
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
(Enforcement of Pledges on Movables)



        Conclusion:
        If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 353 specifically states that the pledgee can recover possession by filing an action for recovery of possession if the pledged thing is usurped, not that they can demand return based on the pledge itself. The premise does not mention the right to demand return based on the pledge, only the recovery of possession of the pledged item if it is usurped.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 103:
An agent who has no specifically defined authority has the authority to perform the following acts only:
(i) acts of preservation; and
(ii) acts with the purpose of using or improving a thing or right that is the subject matter of the agency, to the extent that this does not change the nature of that thing or right.
(Appointment of Subagents by Agents)



        Conclusion:
        An agent who has no specified authority shall have the authority only to do the acts of preservation..'''
argument: The conclusion does not fully reflect the scope of authority as described in Article 103, as it omits the agent's authority to perform acts with the purpose of using or improving the subject matter of the agency, which was included in the original article.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 646:
(1) A mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business. The same applies to fruits the mandatary has reaped.
(2) A mandatary must transfer to the mandator rights that the mandatary has acquired in the mandatary's own name on behalf of the mandator.
(Mandatary's Responsibility for Consumption of Monies)



        Conclusion:
        The mandatary is not obligated to deliver to the mandator civil fruits reaped during the course of administering the mandated business..'''
argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 646(1) which states that the mandatary must deliver to the mandator not only monies and other things received but also fruits reaped. Since civil fruits are a form of fruits reaped, the conclusion that the mandatary is not obligated to deliver civil fruits is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 140:
When a period is provided for in days, weeks, months, or years, the first day of the period is not included in the computation; provided, however, that this does not apply when the period commences at twelve midnight.
(Expiration of Period)



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 3:00 p.m. on May 16 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within one week, the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 140, which states that the first day of the period is not included in the computation unless the period commences at twelve midnight. The conclusion assumes that the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day without explicitly stating that the agreement was made at twelve midnight, thus it is not necessarily true that the period starts at midnight based solely on the given premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 487:
If there is an instrument evidencing a claim and the person making the performance has made full performance, that person may demand the return of the instrument.
(Appropriation of One Payment or Delivery among Two or More Obligations Requiring the Same Kind of Payment or Delivery)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where there is any instrument which evidences the claim for wages, the borrower may assert the fact that he/she will make a payment by returning and exchanging the instrument when attempting to make the performance has completed his/her entire performance..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 487 specifically refers to an instrument evidencing a claim and the appropriation of one payment or delivery among two or more obligations requiring the same kind of payment or delivery. It does not explicitly state or imply that this applies to the specific case of wages or the borrower's right to exchange the instrument when attempting to fulfill a performance obligation. The premise does not provide enough context or specificity to support the conclusion that the borrower may assert the fact of returning and exchanging the instrument specifically for wages.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 300:
The exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims.
(Extinction of Rights of Retention by Provision of Security)



        Conclusion:
        The extinctive prescription of the claim secured by the right of retention does not run while the holder of the right of retention exercises the right of retention and retains the subject matter..'''
argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 300, which states that the exercise of a right of retention does not affect the running of extinctive prescription for claims. Therefore, the prescription period should continue to run even if the right of retention is exercised.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 655:
The grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of or knew of the same.
(Quasi-Mandate)



        Conclusion:
        Regardless of the other party's knowledge, the grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of the same..'''
argument: The conclusion does not fully capture the intent of Article 655, as it omits the condition that the grounds of termination may not be asserted if the other party 'knew of the same' without needing notification. This implies that there are two conditions for not being able to assert the grounds of termination: either the other party was not notified, or they did not know about it, which the conclusion simplifies to only the notification condition.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 371:
If there is a default with respect to a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default.
(Mutatis Mutandis Application of Provisions on Right of Retention)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a mortgagor lease land which is a subject matter of the mortgage to a person, the mortgage shall extend to the rent without a default with respect to a claim secured by the mortgage..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 371 specifically states that the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables only after a default with respect to a claim secured by the mortgage. The conclusion, however, claims that the mortgage extends to the rent without any default having occurred.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 244:
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
(Mixture)



        Conclusion:
        If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise as Article 244 does not mention any role for a court in determining ownership when the distinction between principal and accessory cannot be made. The article only specifies how ownership is shared when the movables are mixed, without indicating a need for judicial intervention to determine ownership.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 406:
If the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice being made from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.
(Exercise of Right to Choose)



        Conclusion:
        If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 406 specifies that the right to choose belongs to the obligor only if the subject matter of the claim is determined by a choice among more than one performance, but it does not explicitly state that this right persists in the absence of a special provision. The premise does not cover all scenarios, particularly those where special provisions might alter or negate the obligor's right to choose.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 632:
A contract for work become effective when one of the parties promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work.
(Timing of Payment of Remuneration)



        Conclusion:
        The contractor may not claim his/her remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount..'''
argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise provided. Article 632 states the conditions under which a contract for work becomes effective, but it does not specify that the contractor may not claim remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount. The premise only mentions the promises made by the parties regarding the completion of work and payment of remuneration, but does not address the conditions under which the contractor can claim the remuneration.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 134:
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
(Effect of Arrival of Assigned Time)



        Conclusion:
        A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent shall be void if the condition is dependent upon the will of the obligor..'''
argument: The conclusion uses the term 'will of the obligor' which is not explicitly stated in Article 134. Article 134 specifies that the condition is void if it is dependent 'only upon the intention of the obligor', which is slightly different from 'dependent upon the will of the obligor'. The term 'will' could imply a broader range of conditions beyond just 'intention', thus the conclusion may not be logically entailed by the given premise.
